S1.T1.caption:
Table 1: Communication and computation cost of the proposed CCESA algorithm, scalable secure aggregation algorithm in parallel work (Bell et al., 2020), Secure Aggregation (SA) in (Bonawitz et al., 2017).
Detailed derivations of complexity are given in Appendix C.
references: We propose communication-computation efficient secure aggregation (CCESA) algorithm, which maintains the reliability and data privacy in federated learning with reduced resources on communication and computation compared to conventional secure aggregation of (Bonawitz et al., 2017). The key idea is to replace the complete graph topology of (Bonawitz et al., 2017) with a low-degree graph for resource efficiency, as illustrated in Fig. 1. Under the threat of eavesdroppers, we first provide the necessary and sufficient condition on the sparse graph topology for private and reliable secure aggregation and suggest an explicit graph design rule based on a conceptually simple Erdos-Renyi graph. As a consequence, the required resources of the proposed CCESA reduce by a factor of at least O​(n/log⁡n)𝑂𝑛𝑛O(\sqrt{n/\log n}) compared to (Bonawitz et al., 2017). Here, we acknowledge that parallel work (Bell et al., 2020) utilizes a Harary graph topology where each client more effectively selects the clients sharing its secret, and consequently further reduces communication/computation costs of secure aggregation. Detailed comparisons are given in Table 1. Our mathematical results are also confirmed in experiments on two real datasets of AT&T face database and CIFAR-10, under practical attack scenarios including the model inversion attack and the membership inference attack. Especially, under the model inversion attack on the face dataset, the results in Fig. 2 show that the suggested scheme achieves near-perfect data privacy by using less amount of resources than SA, while federated averaging without security measures (McMahan et al., 2017) significantly compromises the privacy of the data.

In the remarks below, we compare SA and the proposed CCESA, in terms of the required amount of communication/computational resources to achieve both reliability and privacy. These results are summarized in Table 1.

In Table 5.1, we tested the running time of our CCESA and existing SA for various n𝑛n and qtotalsubscript𝑞totalq_{\text{total}}. Similar to the setup used in (Bonawitz et al., 2017), we assumed that each node has its local model 𝜽𝜽\bm{\theta} with dimension m=10000𝑚10000m=10000, where each element of the model is chosen from the field 𝔽216subscript𝔽superscript216\mathbb{F}_{2^{16}}. Here, t𝑡t is selected by following the guideline
in Appendix E, and p𝑝p is chosen as p⋆∼O​(log⁡n/n)similar-tosuperscript𝑝⋆𝑂𝑛𝑛p^{\star}\sim O(\sqrt{\log n/n}) defined in (5) which is proven to meet both reliability and privacy conditions.
For every n,qtotal𝑛subscript𝑞totaln,q_{\text{total}} setup, the proposed CCESA(n,p𝑛𝑝n,p) requires p𝑝p times less running time compared with the conventional SA of (Bonawitz et al., 2017).
This is because each client generates p𝑝p times less number of secret shares and pseudo-random values, and performs p𝑝p times less number of key agreements. This result is consistent with our analysis on the computational complexity in Table 1.

as n𝑛n increases, showing the scalability of CCESA.
These results are summarized in Table 1.

We evaluate the computational cost of CCESA.
Here we do not count the cost for computing the signatures since it is negligible. First, we derive the computational cost of each client.
Given the number of model parameters m𝑚m and the number of clients n𝑛n, the computational cost of client i𝑖i is composed of three parts:
(1) computing 2​|A​d​j​(i)|2𝐴𝑑𝑗𝑖2|Adj(i)| key agreements, which takes O​(|A​d​j​(i)|)𝑂𝐴𝑑𝑗𝑖O(|Adj(i)|) time,
(2) generating shares of tisubscript𝑡𝑖t_{i}-out-of-|A​d​j​(i)|𝐴𝑑𝑗𝑖|Adj(i)| secret shares of siS​Ksuperscriptsubscript𝑠𝑖𝑆𝐾s_{i}^{SK} and bisubscript𝑏𝑖b_{i}, which takes O​(|A​d​j​(i)|2)𝑂superscript𝐴𝑑𝑗𝑖2O(|Adj(i)|^{2}) time, and
(3) generating masked local model θ~isubscript~𝜃𝑖\tilde{\theta}_{i}, which requires O​(m​|A​d​j​(i)|)𝑂𝑚𝐴𝑑𝑗𝑖O(m|Adj(i)|) time.
Thus, the total computational cost of each client is obtained as O​(|A​d​j​(i)|2+m​|A​d​j​(i)|)𝑂superscript𝐴𝑑𝑗𝑖2𝑚𝐴𝑑𝑗𝑖O(|Adj(i)|^{2}+m|Adj(i)|).
Second, the server’s computational cost is composed of two parts:
(1) reconstructing tisubscript𝑡𝑖t_{i}-out-of-|A​d​j​(i)|𝐴𝑑𝑗𝑖|Adj(i)| secrets from shares for all clients i∈[n]𝑖delimited-[]𝑛i\in[n], which requires O​(n​|A​d​j​(i)|2)𝑂𝑛superscript𝐴𝑑𝑗𝑖2O(n|Adj(i)|^{2}) time, and (2) removing masks from masked sum of local models ∑i=1nθ~isuperscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑛subscript~𝜃𝑖\sum_{i=1}^{n}\tilde{\theta}_{i}, which requires O​(m​|A​d​j​(i)|2)𝑂𝑚superscript𝐴𝑑𝑗𝑖2O(m|Adj(i)|^{2}) time in the worst case.
As a result, the total computational cost of the server is O​(m​|A​d​j​(i)|2)𝑂𝑚superscript𝐴𝑑𝑗𝑖2O(m|Adj(i)|^{2}).
If we choose p=(1+ϵ)​p⋆𝑝1italic-ϵsuperscript𝑝⋆p=(1+\epsilon)p^{\star} for small ϵ>0italic-ϵ0\epsilon>0, the total computational cost per each client is O​(n​log⁡n+m​n​log⁡n)𝑂𝑛𝑛𝑚𝑛𝑛O(n\log n+m\sqrt{n\log n}), while the total computation cost of the server is O​(m​n​log⁡n+n2​log⁡n)𝑂𝑚𝑛𝑛superscript𝑛2𝑛O(mn\log n+n^{2}\log n).
The computational cost of SA can be obtained in a similar manner, by setting A​d​j​(i)=n−1𝐴𝑑𝑗𝑖𝑛1Adj(i)=n-1; each client requires O​(n2+m​n)𝑂superscript𝑛2𝑚𝑛O(n^{2}+mn) time while the server requires O​(m​n2)𝑂𝑚superscript𝑛2O(mn^{2}) time. These results are summarized in Table 1.

Combining the above two lemmas, we conclude that CCESA(n,p⋆𝑛superscript𝑝⋆n,p^{\star}) is private with probability ≥1−O​(n−C)absent1𝑂superscript𝑛𝐶\geq 1-O(n^{-C}) for arbitrary C>0𝐶0C>0.
These results on the reliability and the privacy are summarized in Table 1.

in Appendix E, and p𝑝p is chosen as p⋆∼O​(log⁡n/n)similar-tosuperscript𝑝⋆𝑂𝑛𝑛p^{\star}\sim O(\sqrt{\log n/n}) defined in (5) which is proven to meet both reliability and privacy conditions.

S5.T2.caption:
Table 5.2: Accuracy of the membership inference attack on local models trained on CIFAR-10. The scheme with a higher attack accuracy is more vulnerable to the inference attack.
In order to maximize the uncertainty of the membership inference,
the test set for the attack model consists of 500050005000 members (training data points) and 500050005000 non-members (evaluation data points).
For the proposed CCESA, the attacker is no better than the random guess with accuracy = 50%percent5050\%, showing the privacy-preserving ability of CCESA.

Schemes \\\backslash Number of training data (ntrainsubscript𝑛trainn_{\text{train}}) 500050005000 100001000010000 150001500015000 500005000050000
Federated Averaging (McMahan et al., 2017) 72.49% 70.72% 72.80% 66.47%

references:
We first consider a privacy threat called model inversion attack (Fredrikson et al., 2015). The basic setup is as follows: the attacker eavesdrops the masked model θ~isubscript~𝜃𝑖\tilde{\theta}_{i} sent from client i𝑖i to the server, and reconstructs the face image of a target client. Under this setting, we compared how the eavesdropped model reveals the information on the raw data for various schemes. As in Fig. 2 and Fig. A.4 in Appendix A.2, the vanilla federated averaging (McMahan et al., 2017) with no privacy-preserving techniques reveals the characteristics of individual’s face, compromising the privacy of clients.
On the other hand, both SA and CCESA do not allow any clue on the client’s face; these schemes are resilient to the model inversion attack and preserve the privacy of clients.
This observation is consistent with our theoretical results
that the proposed CCESA guarantees data privacy.
We also considered another privacy threat called the membership inference attack (Shokri et al., 2017). Here, the attacker eavesdrops the masked model θ~isubscript~𝜃𝑖\tilde{\theta}_{i} and guesses whether a target data is a member of the training dataset.
Table 5.2 summarizes the accuracy
of the inference attack for CIFAR-10 dataset, under the federated learning setup where ntrainsubscript𝑛trainn_{\text{train}} training data is equally distributed into n=10𝑛10n=10 clients.
The attack accuracy reaches near 70%percent7070\% for federated averaging, while SA and CCESA have the attack accuracy of near 50%percent5050\%, similar to the performance of the random guess.

In Section 5.3, we have also considered another type of privacy threat called membership inference attack (Shokri et al., 2017), where the attacker observes masked local model θ~isubscript~𝜃𝑖\tilde{\theta}_{i} sent from client i𝑖i to the server, and guesses whether a particular data is the member of the training set.
We measured three types of performance metrics of the attacker: accuracy (the fraction of the records correctly estimated the membership), precision (the fraction of the responses inferred as members of the training dataset that are indeed members) and recall (the fraction of the training data that the attacker can correctly infer as members).
Table 5.2 summarizes the attack accuracy result, while Table A.3 shows the attack precision for CIFAR-10 dataset.
We also observed that recall is close to 111 for all schemes.
Similar to the results on the attack accuracy, Table A.3 shows that the attack precision of federated averaging reaches near 70%percent7070\%, while that of SA and CCESA remain around the baseline performance of random guess.
This shows that both SA and CCESA do not reveal any clue on the training set.

Table A.3: Precision of the membership inference attack on local models trained on CIFAR-10. The scheme with a higher attack precision is more vulnerable to the inference attack.
For the proposed CCESA, the attacker is no better than the random guess with precision = 50%percent5050\%, showing the privacy-preserving ability of CCESA.

references: We propose communication-computation efficient secure aggregation (CCESA) algorithm, which maintains the reliability and data privacy in federated learning with reduced resources on communication and computation compared to conventional secure aggregation of (Bonawitz et al., 2017). The key idea is to replace the complete graph topology of (Bonawitz et al., 2017) with a low-degree graph for resource efficiency, as illustrated in Fig. 1. Under the threat of eavesdroppers, we first provide the necessary and sufficient condition on the sparse graph topology for private and reliable secure aggregation and suggest an explicit graph design rule based on a conceptually simple Erdos-Renyi graph. As a consequence, the required resources of the proposed CCESA reduce by a factor of at least O​(n/log⁡n)𝑂𝑛𝑛O(\sqrt{n/\log n}) compared to (Bonawitz et al., 2017). Here, we acknowledge that parallel work (Bell et al., 2020) utilizes a Harary graph topology where each client more effectively selects the clients sharing its secret, and consequently further reduces communication/computation costs of secure aggregation. Detailed comparisons are given in Table 1. Our mathematical results are also confirmed in experiments on two real datasets of AT&T face database and CIFAR-10, under practical attack scenarios including the model inversion attack and the membership inference attack. Especially, under the model inversion attack on the face dataset, the results in Fig. 2 show that the suggested scheme achieves near-perfect data privacy by using less amount of resources than SA, while federated averaging without security measures (McMahan et al., 2017) significantly compromises the privacy of the data.

Another popular approach is deploying secure multiparty computation (MPC)  (Ben-Or et al., 1988; Damgård et al., 2012; Aono et al., 2017; Lindell et al., 2015; Bonawitz et al., 2017; Zhang et al., 2018; Tjell & Wisniewski, 2019; Shen et al., 2020; So et al., 2020) based on the cryptographic primitives including secret sharing and the homomorphic encryption (Leontiadis et al., 2014; 2015; Shi et al., 2011; Halevi et al., 2011).
Although these schemes guarantee privacy, they suffer from high communication burdens while reconstructing the secret information distributed over multiple clients.
A notable work (Bonawitz et al., 2017) suggested secure aggregation (SA), which tolerates multiple client failures by applying pairwise additive masking (Ács & Castelluccia, 2011; Elahi et al., 2014; Jansen & Johnson, 2016; Goryczka & Xiong, 2015).
A recent work (So et al., 2020) suggested Turbo-aggregate, an approach based on the circular aggregation topology to achieve a significant computation/communication complexity reduction in secure aggregation.
However, each client in Turbo-aggregate requires a communication cost of at least 4​m​n​R/L4𝑚𝑛𝑅𝐿4mnR/L bits, which is much larger than that of our scheme (CCESA) requiring a communication cost of n​log⁡n​(2​aK+5​aS)+m​R𝑛𝑛2subscript𝑎𝐾5subscript𝑎𝑆𝑚𝑅\sqrt{n\log n}(2a_{K}+5a_{S})+mR111Here, m𝑚m is the number of model parameters where each parameter is represented in R𝑅R bits. L𝐿L is the number of client groups in Turbo-aggregate. aKsubscript𝑎𝐾a_{K} and aSsubscript𝑎𝑆a_{S} are the number of bits required for exchanging public keys and the number of bits in a secret share, respectively.. For example, in a practical scenario with m=106,R=32,n=100,L=10formulae-sequence𝑚superscript106formulae-sequence𝑅32formulae-sequence𝑛100𝐿10m=10^{6},R=32,n=100,L=10 and aK=aS=256subscript𝑎𝐾subscript𝑎𝑆256a_{K}=a_{S}=256, our scheme requires only 3%percent33\% of the communication bandwidth used in Turbo-aggregate.

In the remarks below, we compare SA and the proposed CCESA, in terms of the required amount of communication/computational resources to achieve both reliability and privacy. These results are summarized in Table 1.

In Table 5.1, we tested the running time of our CCESA and existing SA for various n𝑛n and qtotalsubscript𝑞totalq_{\text{total}}. Similar to the setup used in (Bonawitz et al., 2017), we assumed that each node has its local model 𝜽𝜽\bm{\theta} with dimension m=10000𝑚10000m=10000, where each element of the model is chosen from the field 𝔽216subscript𝔽superscript216\mathbb{F}_{2^{16}}. Here, t𝑡t is selected by following the guideline
in Appendix E, and p𝑝p is chosen as p⋆∼O​(log⁡n/n)similar-tosuperscript𝑝⋆𝑂𝑛𝑛p^{\star}\sim O(\sqrt{\log n/n}) defined in (5) which is proven to meet both reliability and privacy conditions.
For every n,qtotal𝑛subscript𝑞totaln,q_{\text{total}} setup, the proposed CCESA(n,p𝑛𝑝n,p) requires p𝑝p times less running time compared with the conventional SA of (Bonawitz et al., 2017).
This is because each client generates p𝑝p times less number of secret shares and pseudo-random values, and performs p𝑝p times less number of key agreements. This result is consistent with our analysis on the computational complexity in Table 1.

We first consider a privacy threat called model inversion attack (Fredrikson et al., 2015). The basic setup is as follows: the attacker eavesdrops the masked model θ~isubscript~𝜃𝑖\tilde{\theta}_{i} sent from client i𝑖i to the server, and reconstructs the face image of a target client. Under this setting, we compared how the eavesdropped model reveals the information on the raw data for various schemes. As in Fig. 2 and Fig. A.4 in Appendix A.2, the vanilla federated averaging (McMahan et al., 2017) with no privacy-preserving techniques reveals the characteristics of individual’s face, compromising the privacy of clients.
On the other hand, both SA and CCESA do not allow any clue on the client’s face; these schemes are resilient to the model inversion attack and preserve the privacy of clients.
This observation is consistent with our theoretical results
that the proposed CCESA guarantees data privacy.
We also considered another privacy threat called the membership inference attack (Shokri et al., 2017). Here, the attacker eavesdrops the masked model θ~isubscript~𝜃𝑖\tilde{\theta}_{i} and guesses whether a target data is a member of the training dataset.
Table 5.2 summarizes the accuracy
of the inference attack for CIFAR-10 dataset, under the federated learning setup where ntrainsubscript𝑛trainn_{\text{train}} training data is equally distributed into n=10𝑛10n=10 clients.
The attack accuracy reaches near 70%percent7070\% for federated averaging, while SA and CCESA have the attack accuracy of near 50%percent5050\%, similar to the performance of the random guess.

In Section 5.3, we have also considered another type of privacy threat called membership inference attack (Shokri et al., 2017), where the attacker observes masked local model θ~isubscript~𝜃𝑖\tilde{\theta}_{i} sent from client i𝑖i to the server, and guesses whether a particular data is the member of the training set.
We measured three types of performance metrics of the attacker: accuracy (the fraction of the records correctly estimated the membership), precision (the fraction of the responses inferred as members of the training dataset that are indeed members) and recall (the fraction of the training data that the attacker can correctly infer as members).
Table 5.2 summarizes the attack accuracy result, while Table A.3 shows the attack precision for CIFAR-10 dataset.
We also observed that recall is close to 111 for all schemes.
Similar to the results on the attack accuracy, Table A.3 shows that the attack precision of federated averaging reaches near 70%percent7070\%, while that of SA and CCESA remain around the baseline performance of random guess.
This shows that both SA and CCESA do not reveal any clue on the training set.

as n𝑛n increases, showing the scalability of CCESA.
These results are summarized in Table 1.

We evaluate the computational cost of CCESA.
Here we do not count the cost for computing the signatures since it is negligible. First, we derive the computational cost of each client.
Given the number of model parameters m𝑚m and the number of clients n𝑛n, the computational cost of client i𝑖i is composed of three parts:
(1) computing 2​|A​d​j​(i)|2𝐴𝑑𝑗𝑖2|Adj(i)| key agreements, which takes O​(|A​d​j​(i)|)𝑂𝐴𝑑𝑗𝑖O(|Adj(i)|) time,
(2) generating shares of tisubscript𝑡𝑖t_{i}-out-of-|A​d​j​(i)|𝐴𝑑𝑗𝑖|Adj(i)| secret shares of siS​Ksuperscriptsubscript𝑠𝑖𝑆𝐾s_{i}^{SK} and bisubscript𝑏𝑖b_{i}, which takes O​(|A​d​j​(i)|2)𝑂superscript𝐴𝑑𝑗𝑖2O(|Adj(i)|^{2}) time, and
(3) generating masked local model θ~isubscript~𝜃𝑖\tilde{\theta}_{i}, which requires O​(m​|A​d​j​(i)|)𝑂𝑚𝐴𝑑𝑗𝑖O(m|Adj(i)|) time.
Thus, the total computational cost of each client is obtained as O​(|A​d​j​(i)|2+m​|A​d​j​(i)|)𝑂superscript𝐴𝑑𝑗𝑖2𝑚𝐴𝑑𝑗𝑖O(|Adj(i)|^{2}+m|Adj(i)|).
Second, the server’s computational cost is composed of two parts:
(1) reconstructing tisubscript𝑡𝑖t_{i}-out-of-|A​d​j​(i)|𝐴𝑑𝑗𝑖|Adj(i)| secrets from shares for all clients i∈[n]𝑖delimited-[]𝑛i\in[n], which requires O​(n​|A​d​j​(i)|2)𝑂𝑛superscript𝐴𝑑𝑗𝑖2O(n|Adj(i)|^{2}) time, and (2) removing masks from masked sum of local models ∑i=1nθ~isuperscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑛subscript~𝜃𝑖\sum_{i=1}^{n}\tilde{\theta}_{i}, which requires O​(m​|A​d​j​(i)|2)𝑂𝑚superscript𝐴𝑑𝑗𝑖2O(m|Adj(i)|^{2}) time in the worst case.
As a result, the total computational cost of the server is O​(m​|A​d​j​(i)|2)𝑂𝑚superscript𝐴𝑑𝑗𝑖2O(m|Adj(i)|^{2}).
If we choose p=(1+ϵ)​p⋆𝑝1italic-ϵsuperscript𝑝⋆p=(1+\epsilon)p^{\star} for small ϵ>0italic-ϵ0\epsilon>0, the total computational cost per each client is O​(n​log⁡n+m​n​log⁡n)𝑂𝑛𝑛𝑚𝑛𝑛O(n\log n+m\sqrt{n\log n}), while the total computation cost of the server is O​(m​n​log⁡n+n2​log⁡n)𝑂𝑚𝑛𝑛superscript𝑛2𝑛O(mn\log n+n^{2}\log n).
The computational cost of SA can be obtained in a similar manner, by setting A​d​j​(i)=n−1𝐴𝑑𝑗𝑖𝑛1Adj(i)=n-1; each client requires O​(n2+m​n)𝑂superscript𝑛2𝑚𝑛O(n^{2}+mn) time while the server requires O​(m​n2)𝑂𝑚superscript𝑛2O(mn^{2}) time. These results are summarized in Table 1.

Combining the above two lemmas, we conclude that CCESA(n,p⋆𝑛superscript𝑝⋆n,p^{\star}) is private with probability ≥1−O​(n−C)absent1𝑂superscript𝑛𝐶\geq 1-O(n^{-C}) for arbitrary C>0𝐶0C>0.
These results on the reliability and the privacy are summarized in Table 1.

AT&T Face dataset contains images of 404040 members. We allocated the data to n=40𝑛40n=40 clients participating in the federated learning, where each client contains the images of a specific member. This experimental setup is suitable for the practical federated learning scenario where each client has its own image and the central server aggregates the local models for face recognition.
Following the previous work (Fredrikson et al., 2015) on the model inversion, we used softmax regression for the classification. Both the number of local training epochs and the number of global aggregation rounds are set to El​o​c​a​l=Eg​l​o​b​a​l=50subscript𝐸𝑙𝑜𝑐𝑎𝑙subscript𝐸𝑔𝑙𝑜𝑏𝑎𝑙50E_{local}=E_{global}=50, and we used the SGD optimizer with learning rate γ=0.05𝛾0.05\gamma=0.05.

In Fig. 4.1, we select different connection probabilities p=p⋆​(n,qtotal)𝑝superscript𝑝⋆𝑛subscript𝑞totalp=p^{\star}(n,q_{\text{total}}) for various n𝑛n and qtotalsubscript𝑞totalq_{\text{total}}, where p⋆superscript𝑝⋆p^{\star} is defined in (5).
The detailed values of connection probability p𝑝p are provided in Table F.4.

references: We propose communication-computation efficient secure aggregation (CCESA) algorithm, which maintains the reliability and data privacy in federated learning with reduced resources on communication and computation compared to conventional secure aggregation of (Bonawitz et al., 2017). The key idea is to replace the complete graph topology of (Bonawitz et al., 2017) with a low-degree graph for resource efficiency, as illustrated in Fig. 1. Under the threat of eavesdroppers, we first provide the necessary and sufficient condition on the sparse graph topology for private and reliable secure aggregation and suggest an explicit graph design rule based on a conceptually simple Erdos-Renyi graph. As a consequence, the required resources of the proposed CCESA reduce by a factor of at least O​(n/log⁡n)𝑂𝑛𝑛O(\sqrt{n/\log n}) compared to (Bonawitz et al., 2017). Here, we acknowledge that parallel work (Bell et al., 2020) utilizes a Harary graph topology where each client more effectively selects the clients sharing its secret, and consequently further reduces communication/computation costs of secure aggregation. Detailed comparisons are given in Table 1. Our mathematical results are also confirmed in experiments on two real datasets of AT&T face database and CIFAR-10, under practical attack scenarios including the model inversion attack and the membership inference attack. Especially, under the model inversion attack on the face dataset, the results in Fig. 2 show that the suggested scheme achieves near-perfect data privacy by using less amount of resources than SA, while federated averaging without security measures (McMahan et al., 2017) significantly compromises the privacy of the data.

Another popular approach is deploying secure multiparty computation (MPC)  (Ben-Or et al., 1988; Damgård et al., 2012; Aono et al., 2017; Lindell et al., 2015; Bonawitz et al., 2017; Zhang et al., 2018; Tjell & Wisniewski, 2019; Shen et al., 2020; So et al., 2020) based on the cryptographic primitives including secret sharing and the homomorphic encryption (Leontiadis et al., 2014; 2015; Shi et al., 2011; Halevi et al., 2011).
Although these schemes guarantee privacy, they suffer from high communication burdens while reconstructing the secret information distributed over multiple clients.
A notable work (Bonawitz et al., 2017) suggested secure aggregation (SA), which tolerates multiple client failures by applying pairwise additive masking (Ács & Castelluccia, 2011; Elahi et al., 2014; Jansen & Johnson, 2016; Goryczka & Xiong, 2015).
A recent work (So et al., 2020) suggested Turbo-aggregate, an approach based on the circular aggregation topology to achieve a significant computation/communication complexity reduction in secure aggregation.
However, each client in Turbo-aggregate requires a communication cost of at least 4​m​n​R/L4𝑚𝑛𝑅𝐿4mnR/L bits, which is much larger than that of our scheme (CCESA) requiring a communication cost of n​log⁡n​(2​aK+5​aS)+m​R𝑛𝑛2subscript𝑎𝐾5subscript𝑎𝑆𝑚𝑅\sqrt{n\log n}(2a_{K}+5a_{S})+mR111Here, m𝑚m is the number of model parameters where each parameter is represented in R𝑅R bits. L𝐿L is the number of client groups in Turbo-aggregate. aKsubscript𝑎𝐾a_{K} and aSsubscript𝑎𝑆a_{S} are the number of bits required for exchanging public keys and the number of bits in a secret share, respectively.. For example, in a practical scenario with m=106,R=32,n=100,L=10formulae-sequence𝑚superscript106formulae-sequence𝑅32formulae-sequence𝑛100𝐿10m=10^{6},R=32,n=100,L=10 and aK=aS=256subscript𝑎𝐾subscript𝑎𝑆256a_{K}=a_{S}=256, our scheme requires only 3%percent33\% of the communication bandwidth used in Turbo-aggregate.

In the remarks below, we compare SA and the proposed CCESA, in terms of the required amount of communication/computational resources to achieve both reliability and privacy. These results are summarized in Table 1.

In Table 5.1, we tested the running time of our CCESA and existing SA for various n𝑛n and qtotalsubscript𝑞totalq_{\text{total}}. Similar to the setup used in (Bonawitz et al., 2017), we assumed that each node has its local model 𝜽𝜽\bm{\theta} with dimension m=10000𝑚10000m=10000, where each element of the model is chosen from the field 𝔽216subscript𝔽superscript216\mathbb{F}_{2^{16}}. Here, t𝑡t is selected by following the guideline
in Appendix E, and p𝑝p is chosen as p⋆∼O​(log⁡n/n)similar-tosuperscript𝑝⋆𝑂𝑛𝑛p^{\star}\sim O(\sqrt{\log n/n}) defined in (5) which is proven to meet both reliability and privacy conditions.
For every n,qtotal𝑛subscript𝑞totaln,q_{\text{total}} setup, the proposed CCESA(n,p𝑛𝑝n,p) requires p𝑝p times less running time compared with the conventional SA of (Bonawitz et al., 2017).
This is because each client generates p𝑝p times less number of secret shares and pseudo-random values, and performs p𝑝p times less number of key agreements. This result is consistent with our analysis on the computational complexity in Table 1.

We first consider a privacy threat called model inversion attack (Fredrikson et al., 2015). The basic setup is as follows: the attacker eavesdrops the masked model θ~isubscript~𝜃𝑖\tilde{\theta}_{i} sent from client i𝑖i to the server, and reconstructs the face image of a target client. Under this setting, we compared how the eavesdropped model reveals the information on the raw data for various schemes. As in Fig. 2 and Fig. A.4 in Appendix A.2, the vanilla federated averaging (McMahan et al., 2017) with no privacy-preserving techniques reveals the characteristics of individual’s face, compromising the privacy of clients.
On the other hand, both SA and CCESA do not allow any clue on the client’s face; these schemes are resilient to the model inversion attack and preserve the privacy of clients.
This observation is consistent with our theoretical results
that the proposed CCESA guarantees data privacy.
We also considered another privacy threat called the membership inference attack (Shokri et al., 2017). Here, the attacker eavesdrops the masked model θ~isubscript~𝜃𝑖\tilde{\theta}_{i} and guesses whether a target data is a member of the training dataset.
Table 5.2 summarizes the accuracy
of the inference attack for CIFAR-10 dataset, under the federated learning setup where ntrainsubscript𝑛trainn_{\text{train}} training data is equally distributed into n=10𝑛10n=10 clients.
The attack accuracy reaches near 70%percent7070\% for federated averaging, while SA and CCESA have the attack accuracy of near 50%percent5050\%, similar to the performance of the random guess.

In Section 5.3, we have also considered another type of privacy threat called membership inference attack (Shokri et al., 2017), where the attacker observes masked local model θ~isubscript~𝜃𝑖\tilde{\theta}_{i} sent from client i𝑖i to the server, and guesses whether a particular data is the member of the training set.
We measured three types of performance metrics of the attacker: accuracy (the fraction of the records correctly estimated the membership), precision (the fraction of the responses inferred as members of the training dataset that are indeed members) and recall (the fraction of the training data that the attacker can correctly infer as members).
Table 5.2 summarizes the attack accuracy result, while Table A.3 shows the attack precision for CIFAR-10 dataset.
We also observed that recall is close to 111 for all schemes.
Similar to the results on the attack accuracy, Table A.3 shows that the attack precision of federated averaging reaches near 70%percent7070\%, while that of SA and CCESA remain around the baseline performance of random guess.
This shows that both SA and CCESA do not reveal any clue on the training set.

as n𝑛n increases, showing the scalability of CCESA.
These results are summarized in Table 1.

We evaluate the computational cost of CCESA.
Here we do not count the cost for computing the signatures since it is negligible. First, we derive the computational cost of each client.
Given the number of model parameters m𝑚m and the number of clients n𝑛n, the computational cost of client i𝑖i is composed of three parts:
(1) computing 2​|A​d​j​(i)|2𝐴𝑑𝑗𝑖2|Adj(i)| key agreements, which takes O​(|A​d​j​(i)|)𝑂𝐴𝑑𝑗𝑖O(|Adj(i)|) time,
(2) generating shares of tisubscript𝑡𝑖t_{i}-out-of-|A​d​j​(i)|𝐴𝑑𝑗𝑖|Adj(i)| secret shares of siS​Ksuperscriptsubscript𝑠𝑖𝑆𝐾s_{i}^{SK} and bisubscript𝑏𝑖b_{i}, which takes O​(|A​d​j​(i)|2)𝑂superscript𝐴𝑑𝑗𝑖2O(|Adj(i)|^{2}) time, and
(3) generating masked local model θ~isubscript~𝜃𝑖\tilde{\theta}_{i}, which requires O​(m​|A​d​j​(i)|)𝑂𝑚𝐴𝑑𝑗𝑖O(m|Adj(i)|) time.
Thus, the total computational cost of each client is obtained as O​(|A​d​j​(i)|2+m​|A​d​j​(i)|)𝑂superscript𝐴𝑑𝑗𝑖2𝑚𝐴𝑑𝑗𝑖O(|Adj(i)|^{2}+m|Adj(i)|).
Second, the server’s computational cost is composed of two parts:
(1) reconstructing tisubscript𝑡𝑖t_{i}-out-of-|A​d​j​(i)|𝐴𝑑𝑗𝑖|Adj(i)| secrets from shares for all clients i∈[n]𝑖delimited-[]𝑛i\in[n], which requires O​(n​|A​d​j​(i)|2)𝑂𝑛superscript𝐴𝑑𝑗𝑖2O(n|Adj(i)|^{2}) time, and (2) removing masks from masked sum of local models ∑i=1nθ~isuperscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑛subscript~𝜃𝑖\sum_{i=1}^{n}\tilde{\theta}_{i}, which requires O​(m​|A​d​j​(i)|2)𝑂𝑚superscript𝐴𝑑𝑗𝑖2O(m|Adj(i)|^{2}) time in the worst case.
As a result, the total computational cost of the server is O​(m​|A​d​j​(i)|2)𝑂𝑚superscript𝐴𝑑𝑗𝑖2O(m|Adj(i)|^{2}).
If we choose p=(1+ϵ)​p⋆𝑝1italic-ϵsuperscript𝑝⋆p=(1+\epsilon)p^{\star} for small ϵ>0italic-ϵ0\epsilon>0, the total computational cost per each client is O​(n​log⁡n+m​n​log⁡n)𝑂𝑛𝑛𝑚𝑛𝑛O(n\log n+m\sqrt{n\log n}), while the total computation cost of the server is O​(m​n​log⁡n+n2​log⁡n)𝑂𝑚𝑛𝑛superscript𝑛2𝑛O(mn\log n+n^{2}\log n).
The computational cost of SA can be obtained in a similar manner, by setting A​d​j​(i)=n−1𝐴𝑑𝑗𝑖𝑛1Adj(i)=n-1; each client requires O​(n2+m​n)𝑂superscript𝑛2𝑚𝑛O(n^{2}+mn) time while the server requires O​(m​n2)𝑂𝑚superscript𝑛2O(mn^{2}) time. These results are summarized in Table 1.

Combining the above two lemmas, we conclude that CCESA(n,p⋆𝑛superscript𝑝⋆n,p^{\star}) is private with probability ≥1−O​(n−C)absent1𝑂superscript𝑛𝐶\geq 1-O(n^{-C}) for arbitrary C>0𝐶0C>0.
These results on the reliability and the privacy are summarized in Table 1.

AT&T Face dataset contains images of 404040 members. We allocated the data to n=40𝑛40n=40 clients participating in the federated learning, where each client contains the images of a specific member. This experimental setup is suitable for the practical federated learning scenario where each client has its own image and the central server aggregates the local models for face recognition.
Following the previous work (Fredrikson et al., 2015) on the model inversion, we used softmax regression for the classification. Both the number of local training epochs and the number of global aggregation rounds are set to El​o​c​a​l=Eg​l​o​b​a​l=50subscript𝐸𝑙𝑜𝑐𝑎𝑙subscript𝐸𝑔𝑙𝑜𝑏𝑎𝑙50E_{local}=E_{global}=50, and we used the SGD optimizer with learning rate γ=0.05𝛾0.05\gamma=0.05.
